coredata.dc:title: Identification of two tilted adsorbed μ2-methoxy species on Ni{110} using RAIRS
coredata.dc:creator: Dastoor, H.E.
Gardner, P.
King, D.A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Two different adsorbed methoxy species on Ni{110} are identified using reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy both of which are twofold coordinated and tilted with respect to the surface normal. One methoxy species is adsorbed onto short bridge sites on the close-packed rows, with a large tilt angle in the [001] direction. The other methoxy species is adsorbed at a long bridge site across the close-packed rows and tilted with a smaller angle in the [1 1 0] direction. We also report a remarkable similarity between the infrared data for methoxy adsorption on the same single crystal faces of Ni and Cu, indicating that the nature of the chemisorbed species is determined by the site symmetries on the different planes, and not by the metal itself.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETFERS 16 July 1993 1. Introduction Over recent years there has been much contro- versy over the geometry and bonding site of the sur- face methoxy species. Infrared studies have been car- riedoutformethoxyonCu{100} [l],Cu{1ll} [21 and Ni{ ill } [3] surfaces with the purpose of de- termining the orientation with the aid of the metal surface selection rule. However, whilst the details of the absorptions in the C H stretching region are es- sentially the same (three bands at ~2900, ~2877, ~u2800 cm ) there have been differences in the band assignment and thus differences in the geo- metric interpretation. All authors are in agreement that the band at ~2800 cm should be assigned to the symmetric stretching vibration of the methyl group, and that the smaller band at 2877 cm is an overtone of one of the methyl deformations. (Yates and co-workers [31 have in fact suggested that the 2877 cm band could be the second component of the asymmetric stretch which would be JR active if the molecule were tilted with C1 symmetry.) The main controversy however rests with the assignment of the band at 2900 cm . In an early paper, Ryberg assigns the high-fre- quency band at 2901 cm for methoxy on Cu( l00} to the asymmetric stretching vibration and thus finds evidence for a tilted methoxy species [1]. However, Chesters and McCash, using the infrared spectra of a threefold coordinated methoxy in a metal cluster as a reference, assigned the band at 2901 cm_I on Cu{ 111 } to an overtone of an asymmetric defor- mation mode having gained intensity via Fermi res- onance with the lower-frequency fundamental at ~ 2800 cm [2]. They therefore concluded that the methoxy bonded in a threefold site in an upright configuration. A more recent reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS) study of methoxy on Ni{lll} [3] has given an assignment to the three bands in the C H stretching region similar to that of Ryberg and hence suggests a tilted species. Recently, however, a vibrational study of two dif- ferent cluster compounds with methoxy in twofold and threefold coordination sites by Jayasooriya et al. [4] has revealed how sensitive the symmetric C H stretch and the methyl rocking vibrations are to co- ordination. This has allowed these authors to rein- terpret the RAIRS data on all surfaces studied to date. The absorption band at ~2900 cm has been un- ambiguously assigned to one component of the asymmetric stretch of a methoxy species on a two- fold bridging site. Thus the methoxy is concluded to be both tilted and twofold coordinated on all sur- faces thus far studied. Many other techniques have been used to deter- mine the methoxy tilt angle including NEXAFS 0009-2614193/S 06.00 1993 Elsevier Science Publishers By. All rights reserved. 493 Identification of two tilted adsorbed p.2-methoxy species on Ni{ 11 O} using RAIRS H.E. Dastoor, P. Gardner and D.A. King Department of Chemisiry, University of Cambridge, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 JEW, UK Received 6 April 1993; in final form 14 May 1993 Two different adsorbed methoxy species on Ni~ 1 l0} are identified using reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy both of which are twofold coordinated and tilted with respect to the surface normal. One methoxy species is adsorbed onto short bridge sites on the close-packed rows, with a large tilt angle in the 10011 direction. The other methoxy species is adsorbed at a long bridge site across the close-packed rows and tilted with a smaller angle in the Il TOI direction. We also report a remarkable similarity between the infrared data for methoxy adsorption on the same single crystal faces of Ni and Cu, indicating that the nature of the chemisorbed species is determined by the site symmetries on the different planes, and not by the metal itself. Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 July 1993 [5 7], X-ray photoelectron diffraction E 8], X-ray photoemission 9] and HREELS E 101. These stud- ies have also produced conflicting conclusions. In this Letter, we report the results of an infrared study of methoxy on the more open Ni{ 11 0} surface, and although this system has been studied previ- ously by HREELS E Il] our work is at much higher resolution and as a result we are able to abstract more information about the surface structure. We observe for the first time the methyl rocking mode and hence due to the surface infrared selection rule have un- ambiguous proof that the methoxy on Ni{ 110) is tilted. We also report the presence of two methoxy species and using the results of Jayasooriya et al. [4] show that both are bent and twofold coordinated. 2. Experimental All experiments were carried out in a stainless steel UHV chamber interfaced to a Mattson Cygnus 25 FTIR spectrometer [12] equipped also with LEED and AES for crystal characterisation. All infrared spectra are the average of 500 scans at 4 cm res- olution coadded and displayed as a ratio to a back- ground scan. The Ni{ 110) crystal was prepared by repeated argon bombardment and anneal cycles and its cleanliness was checked by recording the RAIR spectrum of the CO/Ni{ 110) system which is sen- sitive to carbon impurities. A methoxy chemisorbed overlayer was prepared by dosing methanol (Aldrich spectroscopic grade 99.9%), which had been further purified by freeze pump thaw cycles, via the back- ground at 180 K. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Meihoxy adsorption at Ni{ 110) Fig. I shows the infrared spectrum of methoxy on Ni{ 110) at 180 K. The bands are assigned with ref- erence to the methoxy cluster data of Jayasooriya et al. [4] and our results along with those of the other methoxy/metal surface studies are summarised in table 1. The two negative absorption bands observed at 2003 and 1874 cm are due to a small amount of CO present in the background spectrum. This CO is perturbed in the presence of adsorbed methoxy and therefore gives rise to an absorption band at 1808 cm in the ratioed spectrum. This amount of CO is equivalent to less than 0.1% of a monolayer. 1f the molecule is tilted with C~ symmetry then we should observe six fundamentals, one of the com- ponents of the asymmetric stretching vibration Vas(CH3), the symmetric stretch v5(CH3), the CO stretch y (CU), the symmetric deformation ~ (CH3), one component of the asymmetric deformation 5as(CHa) and the methyl rock,p(CH3). Although on the twofold symmetric Ni{l 10) surface an upright methoxy surface complex should also have C,, sym- metry, it has been demonstrated for other upright threefold symmetric molecules [14] that the asym- metric deformations and stretches which would be- come active by the reduction in symmetry from C3~. R0 3000 2500 2000 1500 1000 Wavenumbers Fig. 1. RAIR spectra for methoxy adsorbed on Ni{ I 1O~ at 180 K. The insert shows an exploded view of the C H stretching region of the spectrum, the numbers I and 2 refer to the methoxy species giving rise to each band. 494 Mode Gas phase Cu{I11} [2] Cu~l00} [1] Cu{llO} [131 Ni{1ll} 131 Ni{II0} Twofold cluster Threefold cluster p(CO) 1030 1036 1040 1027 1026 1054 1073 1047 v,(CH3) 2837 2818 2787 2797 2X24 2817 2801 2822 2802 2815 2919 v~(CH3) 2987 2918a) 2901 2913 2927 2921 2908 2920 2920 2944 2947 2961 2974 p(CH3) 1112 1154 1153 905 ~ (CH3) 1455 1447 1434 & (CH,) 1477 1478 1455 1441 1451 2x~(CH3) 2942 2882 2861 a~ 2879 2878 2877 2877 2895 2882 2868 Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 July 1993 Table 1 Vibrational frequencies and absorption band assignments for the methoxy species in cluster compounds and adsorbed on single crystal metal surfaces > Bands have been reassigned by Jayasooriya et al. [4] in the light of their cluster data. to C, have negligible dynamic dipoles perpendicular to the surface. Hence these asymmetric modes can- not be seen with RAIRS and the species would ap- pear therefore to maintain C3~, symmetry if upright on the Ni{ 110) surface. Therefore, if the methoxy species is upright ort Ni{ 110) we should observe only the symmetric fundamentals, y8(CH3), o~(CH3) and y (CO). Hence without having to make a controversial as- signment of the bands in the C H stretching region, the presence of the methyl rocking mode (1154 cm ) and an asymmetric deformation mode ([478 cm~) in our spectrum is clear evidence therefore of a tilted methoxy species. Jayasooriya et al. [4] have shown that the methyl rocking mode (p ( CH3)) is very sensitive to coor- dination such that for methoxy in a threefold coor- dinated site it lies below the CO stretching vibration, but for twofold coordination the rock lies above the CO stretching frequency. Our results therefore in- dicate that the methoxy is twofold coordinated to the Ni{ 110) surface. The fact that the methyl rocking mode and asymmetric deformation mode have not been reported for the Cu{ 111) and Ni (111) surfaces may suggest that the methoxy species has a larger tilt angle on Ni{ 110) than on these close-packed surfaces. In the C H stretching region we observe five bands rather than three as reported for the methoxy on Cu{l1l}, Cu{lO0} and Ni{lll} systems studied to date. An exploded view of the C H stretching region is shown in the inset of fig. 1. The small band at 2877 cm is similar in frequency to those observed on the three other surfaces studied and with reference to the cluster results can be assigned to an overtone of one of the deformation modes, having gained in- tensity by Fermi resonance from the fundamental at 2800 cm . The other features in this frequency re- gion are two pairs of bands at 2800 and ~ 2900 cm . We assign these respectively as the symmetric and asymmetric C H stretching modes of two dif- ferent twofold coordinated methoxy species (both tilted). Since we have already ascertained that the molecule is tilted from the appearance of the p(CH3) and oas(CH3) modes it is not unreasonable to assign the bands at 2900 cm to asymmetric stretching modes. This is also supported by the similar ~ as(~~3) frequency for the twofold coordinated methoxy cluster. Now if there were two different species on the sur- face one would expect them to give rise to two dif- ferent v(CO) frequencies. However, the band itself is quite broad (fwhm ~25 cm ) so two distinct bands cannot be resolved. However, there is broad- ening into a shoulder to the lower-wavenumber side of the band and this shoulder becomes more distinct when the surface is heated slightly from 180 to 200 495 Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 July 1993 K. It is also possible to detect a small splitting in the methyl rocking band to lower wavenumber (t 1130 cm ). We therefore assign the lower-frequency compo- nents of the two band pairs in the C H stretching region (2801 and 2908 cm ) to Ihe v~(CH3) and Vas(CHi) modes of one surface species (species 1) and the higher-frequency components (2822 and 2920 cm ) to the v5(CH3) and Pas(CH3) modes of the second species (species 2). A ratio of the v8(CH3) to the vas(CH3) band in- tensities for each species indicates that species 2, with the higher-frequency stretches (4/Ias=0.6), is more tilted than methoxy species 1, with the lower-fre- quency C H stretches (~ s/~as 1.2). This is in agree- ment with the model proposed by Jayasooriya et al. [4] to explain the variation in stretching frequencies with tilt angle. They suggest that the interaction of the oxygen lone pair with the surface increases as the tilt angle increases and hence its overlap with the an- tibonding orbital on the C H bond trans to it is cor- respondingly reduced. The C H stretching frequen- cies are predicted, therefore, to increase with increasing tilt angle as seen for this system. Our conclusions are similar to those of Holub- Krappe et al. [8] for methoxy on Cu{1 10}. They have shown that their X-ray photoelectron diffraction re- sults can only be explained by the presence of two different methoxy species, one tilted by 180 30 in the [110] direction and the other tilted by 400 50 in the [100] direction. Since RAIR spectra of meth- oxy on Cu{l 10) by Bradshaw and co-workers [13] also show five bands in the C H stretching region and the frequencies of the bands are within 4 cm of those reported here it is reasonable to assume a similar structural model for Ni{ 110). lt should be noted also that the infrared frequencies in the C H stretching region for the methoxy on Ni( Ill } [3] and Cu{ 111 } [2] show remarkable similarities in band positions (within 4 cm ), but the v~(CH3) and TMas ( CH3) modes are t 20 cm higher than those for methoxy on Cu{ 100) [1], thus indicating a greater interaction of the lone pair with the surface for the { 111 } faces. The remarkable similarity be- tween the infrared data for the two different (1 l0} surfaces and also between the data for the different 111) surfaces that it is the surface structure that de- termines the allowed interaction of the lone pair with the surface and hence determines the frequency shifts in the C H stretching region and tilt angles more so than the chemical nature of the metal. The similarity between the JR data on the two fcc( 110) surfaces would suggest that methoxy ad- sorption is the same on both surfaces, giving rise to two bridged species one more tilted than the other. With reference to the directional tilts given by Holub- Krappe et al. [8] for methoxy on Cn{ 11 0} we sug- gest that the methoxy species 2, with the higher C H stretching frequencies, bonds at short-bridge sites on the close-packed rows with a large tilt angle (t40 ) across those rows (in the [001] direction). The other methoxy, species 1, may be bonded at long- bridge sites tilted by a smaller angle (t 180) in the [110] direction. Methoxy 2 can be thought of as tilt- ing to attain coordination at a pseudo threefold hollow site, in the same way as has been suggested for bridged methoxy tilting into the threefold hol- lows on the fcc{ 111 } surfaces. Lt is interesting to note that the C H stretching frequencies of the species 2 on Ni{lIl0} match those of methoxy on both {lll} surfaces extremely well, see table 1. Species 2 on Ni{ 110) bonds at a bridge site which is similar in en- vironment to the bridging site on the fcc{ 1 00} sur- face, since tilting in the [110] direction on { 110) takes the methoxy into a pseudo fourfold hollow site and tilting on the { I 00} surface also takes the methoxy into a fourfold hollow site. However, in this comparison the C H stretching frequencies of spe- cies I on Ni{ 110) are actually slightly higher than on Cu( l00} [1]; this may be rationalised by a greater lone pair interaction with the metal for species I since it lies lower in the metal surface. Our proposed sites and geometries for methoxy on Ni{ 1 tO} are shown in fig. 2. 3.2. Surface-cluster analogy In the past, vibrational data for transition metal cluster compounds of known crystal structure have been used as an aid to the assignment of surface in- frared spectra. The most common example of this is the use of carbonyl and nitrosyl metal cluster data to facilitate the site assignment of CO and NO species on single crystal metal surfaces. Quite recently, however, doubt has been cast over the validity of the application of clusters to adsor 496 Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETFERS 16 July 1993 0 Sc H Fig. 2. Proposed sites for methoxy adsorbed onto Ni( 110), The numbers I and 2 refer to the methoxy species as discussed in the text. bate metal systems. For example, Erley has assigned NO as occupying both atop and bridge sites on Ni{ 111 J, depending on coverage, on the basis of fre- quencies seen in nitrosyl clusters [15]. Initial photo- electron diffraction data [161 indicated, however, that NO was in fact coordinated in the threefold hol- low sites at all coverages; this has subsequently been confirmed first by a SEXAFS study [17] and then by tensor LEED [18]. Problems of this nature have also arisen for the CO/Pd(lIO} and CO/Ni{110) systems, where in the saturation coverage (2 X 1 )p,g1 structure the CO has vibrational frequencies 2003 [19] and 1998 cm [201 respectively. These fre- quencies are midway between the ranges normally associated with atop (2050 2150 cm~) and bridge (1850 1950 cm ) sites and therefore the use of or- ganometallic clusters is problematic. A recent tensor LEED study of the CO/Pd{1 10) system [21] has in- dicated that the CO site is in fact atop, but other in- formation regarding the corresponding Ni{ 110) sys- tem indicates conversely that the CO site on this surface is bridge. Hence, one has to be very careful when applying vibrational cluster data to RAIR data of adsorbate surface systems. However, in the case of methoxy adsorption on single crystal metal surfaces we feel that the analogy between cluster and surface is a valid one for the fol- lowing reasons. Because the C H stretching frequen- cies depend on the overlap between the lone pair on the oxygen atom and the antibonding orbital on the C H bond trans to it, then if that lone pair is used in coordination (as is the case for threefold coor- dination) this overlap is much reduced and the C H stretching frequencies are increased. Therefore, it is the actual coordination, i.e. how many lone pairs are tied up with bonding to the metal, which deter- mines the changes in the C H stretching frequencies and this is therefore a localised property, dependent on local geometry, which is unlikely to be signifi- cantly different in the cluster, where the molecular orbitais are localised, compared with the adsorption on a metal surface where the metal orbitais are de- localised. Also, we find that the frequencies of the twofold coordinated methoxy in the cluster match the surface frequencies very well indeed (see table 1), and are very different to those of the threefold coordinated methoxy cluster. This similarity is un- likely to be just a coincidence, since it seems to occur for all the methoxy/surface systems so far investi- gated. Finally, calculations by Hermann and Meyer [22] for methoxy on a model Cu3 cluster show that the bridge site has a siightly higher binding energy than the threefold site, thus adding weight to our conclusion that methoxy is twofold coordinated on Ni{ 110). 4. Conclusions We have reported the infrared spectrum for meth- oxy adsorbed on Ni{l 10) and with the aid of cluster data [4] have shown that there are two methoxy spe- cies on the Ni{ 110) surface, both twofold coordi- nated and tilted. The two species differ in the fact that one has a larger tilt angle than the other and thus a larger interaction of the extra lone pair on the ox- ygen with the surface. We have demonstrated the similarity in the in- frared data for methoxy adsorption on the same sin- gle crystal planes of nickel and copper and conclude that the behaviour of these two metals is surprisingly similar: the nature of the chemisorbed species is de- termined by the site symmetries on the different planes, and not by the metal itself. Therefore, with reference to our infrared site as- signments and to conclusions drawn from photo- electron diffraction data for methoxy on Cu{ 110), we suggest that the methoxy species on both Ni{ 110) and Cu{1 10} are adsorbed at two different bridge 11T0] ~[O01] 497 Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 July 1993 sites. One methoxy is bound at short-bridge sites along the close-packed rows, tilted by a large angle (~40 [8]) in the [0011 direction, perpendicular to these rows. The other is bound at long-bridge sites, across the close-packed rows, tilted in the [110 J di- rection by a smaller angle (~ 18 [8]). Acknowledgement Our grateful thanks go to Upali Jayasooriya and to John Yates for sending us copies of their manuscript prior to publication. The SERC is acknowledged for an equipment grant, a postdoctoral assistantship (PG) and a studentship (HED). ICI Chemicals and Polymers Ltd. (Katalco) are also acknowledged for a CASE award (HED). Conesa and A.R. Gonzalez-Elipe, Chem. Ph . Letters 192 (1992)259. [17] S. Aminopirooz, A. Schmalz, L. Becker and J. Haase, Phys. Rev.B45 (1992) 6337. [18] L.D. Mapledorum, A. Wander and D.A. King, Chem. Phys. Letters 208 (1993) 409. [19] R. Rayai, MA. Harrison and D.A. King, Surface Sei. 211/ 212 (1989) 61. [20] S. Haq, J.G. Love and D.A. King, Surface Sei. 275 (1992) 170. [21] A. Wander, P. Hu and D.A. King, Chem. Phys. Letters 201 (1993) 393. [22] K. Hermann and C. Meyer, Surface Sei. 269/270 (1992) 326. 498 likely to be just a coincidence, since it seems to occur for all the methoxy/surface systems so far investi- gated. Finally, calculations by Hermann and Meyer [22] for methoxy on a model Cu3 cluster show that the bridge site has a siightly higher binding energy than the threefold site, thus adding weight to our conclusion that methoxy is twofold coordinated on Ni{ 110). 4. Conclusions We have reported the infrared spectrum for meth- oxy adsorbed on Ni{l 10) and with the aid of cluster data [4] have shown that there are two methoxy spe- cies on the Ni{ 110) surface, both twofold coordi- nated and tilted. The two species differ in the fact that one has a larger tilt angle than the other and thus a larger interaction of the extra lone pair on the ox- ygen with the surface. We have demonstrated the similarity in the in- frared data for methoxy adsorption on the same sin- gle crystal planes of nickel and copper and conclude that the behaviour of these two metals is surprisingly similar: the nature of the chemisorbed species is de- termined by the site symmetries on the different planes, and not by the metal itself. Therefore, with reference to our infrared site as- signments and to conclusions drawn from photo- electron diffraction data for methoxy on Cu{ 110), we suggest that the methoxy species on both Ni{ 110) and Cu{1 10} are adsorbed at two different bridge 11T0] ~[O01] 497 Volume 209, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 July 1993 sites. One methoxy is bound at short-bridge sites along the close-packed rows, tilted by a large angle (~40 [8]) in the [0011 direction, perpendicular to these rows. The other is bound at long-bridge sites, across the close-packed rows, tilted in the [110 J di- rection by a smaller angle (~ 18 [8]). Acknowledgement Our grateful thanks go to Upali Jayasooriya and to John Yates for sending us copies of their manuscript prior to publication. head.ce:title: Identification of two tilted adsorbed μ2-methoxy species on Ni{110} using RAIRS

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, University of Cambridge, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, UK

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Two different adsorbed methoxy species on Ni{110} are identified using reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy both of which are twofold coordinated and tilted with respect to the surface normal. One methoxy species is adsorbed onto short bridge sites on the close-packed rows, with a large tilt angle in the [001] direction. The other methoxy species is adsorbed at a long bridge site across the close-packed rows and tilted with a smaller angle in the [1 1 0] direction. We also report a remarkable similarity between the infrared data for methoxy adsorption on the same single crystal faces of Ni and Cu, indicating that the nature of the chemisorbed species is determined by the site symmetries on the different planes, and not by the metal itself.
